conclusion: Identify three states (A, B, C) in a V-T diagram for an ideal gas.
State A: (T₀, V₀), with pressure pA = p₀; State B: (T₀, 2V₀); Line AB is parallel to the V-axis; The extension of line BC passes through the origin O.
The ideal gas law states: PV = nRT.
For a constant mass of gas, P × V / T = constant = nR.
At state A: p₀ × V₀ / T₀ = nR.
At state B: pB × 2V₀ / T₀ = nR, leading to pB = p₀/2.
Point C appears to be at the origin of the V-axis (V = 0) and some temperature TC.
Point C is along the line from origin to B, with coordinates (TC, VC).
For any point on line OB, V/T = 2V₀/T₀.
Point C has coordinates (TC, VC) where VC appears to be V₀/2.
If VC = V₀/2, then TC = T₀/4.
The temperature at state C is TC = T₀/4.
